Trends occur for one of a few reasons (all are business reasons so if you want to try to change the trends good luck with that). So things like electric/hybrid cars, solar cells (yes I know this is primarily electrical but there are mechanical aspects to it), pollution reduction systems, etc.Product improvements is where many of the people in industry look at trends. The biggest trends here I’m going to call interdisciplinary integration (there isn’t really a word for it and people don’t notice it too much they just started doing it). This is the combination of two specialties into a third new specialty, the most obvious of which is mechatronics (the combination of mechanics and electronics). The are other combinations too. Biomechanics is fairly new (has been around for a while but is picking up more steam now), Electronics and materials are combining to make super tiny sensors. mechanical and Aerospace/aeronautical are combining, there are a bunch others and I’m sure I will miss most so I’m going to stop here.The biggest trend (at least in my opinion) is happening in the cost reduction space. Simulation is becoming HUGE, its turning into either you use simulation or your company goes under kinda thing. 20 years ago simulation didn’t really exist in mainstream engineering because of the cost and the amount of computation needed to reach a usable result. Data analytics is also becoming huge. This is going hand in hand with the tiny sensors that the electronics and materials people are making. The idea is that the more sensors you have, the more data you can obtain, the tighter your design tolerances can be, the less waste you make (You can use data analytics for a bunch more than this but this seems to be the popular route in mechanical engineering). Then there is additive manufacturing, most people call this 3D printing but that is a small subset of additive manufacturing. Most manufacturing is done through subtractive manufacturing which is when you continuously remove material until your product is finished. This clearly creates a lot of waste and it becomes incrementally difficult to reclaim this waste material. Additive manufacturing only adds material together until your product is finished which greatly reduces this waste and save money that way.So next time you’re looking for trends (especially in mechanical engineering) remember…1.) interdisciplinary integration is a thing even if there isn’t really a term for it (if someone know of a term for this please let me know because I feel like an idiot for not knowing it).
